required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intraoperative Hypotension and Acute Kidney Injury After Off-pump Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Intraoperative Hypotension on Risk of Acute Kidney Injury After Off-pump Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting Surgery: A Retrospective Cohort Study

brief_summary.textblock: Acute renal injury (AKI) is a common complication after cardiac surgery and is associated with worse outcomes. Hypotension is an important risk factor for the development of AKI after noncardiac surgery. However, the association between intraoperative hypotension and AKI after cardiac surgery has not been fully investigated. The purpose of this study is to analyze the association between intraoperative hypotension and acute kidney injury after off-pump coronary artery bypass surgery.

detailed_description.textblock: Acute renal injury (AKI) is a common complication after cardiac surgery. Cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury (CSA-AKI) is associated with increased in-hospital mortality, prolonged length of stay in the Intensive Care Unit and hospital, and higher costs of care. Intraoperative hypotension is an important risk factor for the development of AKI after noncardiac surgery. In a retrospective analysis, a mean arterial pressure of less than 55 mmHg predicted the occurrence of adverse cardiac- and renal-related outcomes after noncardiac surgery. Other studies also revealed that intraoperative hypotension is associated with increased incidence of AKI and 1-year mortality after noncardiac surgery. In patients undergoing cardiac surgery, 30-day mortality is proportionate to the extent of systolic blood pressure excursions outside the range of 75 to 135 mm Hg intraoperatively. However, the correlation between intraoperative hypotension and the development of AKI after cardiac surgery has not been fully investigated. The purpose of this study is to analyze the association between intraoperative hypotension and the risk of acute kidney injury after off-pump coronary artery bypass surgery.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) within 7 days after surgery
primary_outcome.description: Development of AKI within 7 days after surgery is diagnosed according to the Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) criteria

secondary_outcome.measure: Classification of AKI within 7 days after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Development of AKI within 7 days after surgery is diagnosed according to the KDIGO criteria

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of mechanical ventilation after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Duration of mechanical ventilation after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Length of stay in hospital after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Length of stay in hospital after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Length of stay in intensive care unit (ICU) after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Length of stay in intensive care unit (ICU) after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACEs) within 30 days after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: MACEs within 30 days after surgery include cardiovascular death, non-fatal cardiac arrest, acute myocardial infarction, revascularization, and ischemic stroke.

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of non-MACE complications within 30 days after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Non-MACE complications within 30 days after surgery indicate new-onset medical conditions other than MACEs that produce harmful effects on patients' recovery and required therapeutic intervention.

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing off-pump coronry artery bypass grafting surgery from April 2012 to March 2018 in Peking University First Hospital
